description.level3: Light colored parts of the chromosome - lots of genes here!
description.level4: Light bands that are rich in genes and GC content.
description.level5: G-negative bands are gene-rich regions that don't stain dark with Giemsa dye.
description.level6: Euchromatic regions with high GC content, gene density, and transcriptional activity.
description.level7: G-negative bands represent euchromatin with elevated GC content (~45%) and gene density.
description.level8: G-negative bands correlate with early-replicating, transcriptionally active euchromatin rich in Alu elements.

description.level3: A slightly dark band on the chromosome.
description.level4: A lightly stained band with moderate gene content.
description.level5: Light gray bands with intermediate properties between light and dark bands.
description.level6: Intermediate chromatin with moderate gene density and GC content.
description.level7: G-positive 25% bands show light Giemsa staining with intermediate characteristics.
description.level8: 25% Giemsa-positive bands represent transitional chromatin states between euchromatin and heterochromatin.

description.level3: A medium-dark band on the chromosome.
description.level4: Medium stained bands with fewer genes than light bands.
description.level5: Medium gray bands that stain moderately with Giemsa dye.
description.level6: Heterochromatic regions with moderate AT-richness and reduced gene density.
description.level7: G-positive 50% bands show moderate Giemsa staining and intermediate chromatin condensation.
description.level8: 50% G-positive bands display intermediate characteristics with moderate LINE element enrichment.

description.level3: A dark band on the chromosome - fewer genes here.
description.level4: Dark bands with AT-rich DNA and fewer genes.
description.level5: Dark gray bands that are gene-poor and rich in repetitive DNA.
description.level6: Heterochromatic regions with low gene density, high AT content, and late replication timing.
description.level7: G-positive 75% bands are AT-rich heterochromatin with elevated LINE-1 density.
description.level8: 75% G-positive bands represent late-replicating heterochromatin enriched in LINE elements and depleted in genes.

description.level3: The darkest bands - mostly 'junk DNA' but some is important!
description.level4: The darkest bands with very few genes and lots of repetitive DNA.
description.level5: Heavily stained bands that are very gene-poor and heterochromatic.
description.level6: Constitutive heterochromatin with highest AT content and latest replication timing.
description.level7: G-positive 100% bands represent constitutive heterochromatin with minimal coding content.
description.level8: 100% G-positive bands are AT-rich, late-replicating heterochromatin with highest LINE-1 density and lowest gene expression.

description.level3: The middle part that holds the chromosome together when cells divide!
description.level4: The centromere - where the chromosome gets pulled apart during cell division.
description.level5: The centromere region containing repetitive alpha satellite DNA essential for chromosome segregation.
description.level6: Centromeric heterochromatin with alpha satellite arrays providing the foundation for kinetochore assembly.
description.level7: Centromeric regions contain higher-order alpha satellite repeats that establish CENP-A chromatin domains.
description.level8: Centromeric alpha satellite arrays (171bp monomers in HOR structure) recruit CENP-A nucleosomes for kinetochore function.

description.level3: A part of the chromosome that can be different sizes in different people!
description.level4: Variable regions that differ in size between individuals - harmless variations.
description.level5: Heterochromatic regions that show copy number variation between individuals.
description.level6: Variable heterochromatin regions (e.g., 1qh, 9qh, 16qh) with polymorphic satellite DNA.
description.level7: Heteromorphic regions with variable satellite III and beta satellite content between individuals.
description.level8: Polymorphic heterochromatic variants contain variable tandem repeats considered benign structural variants.

description.level3: The skinny part connecting the short arm to the chromosome body.
description.level4: Stalk regions on acrocentric chromosomes (13, 14, 15, 21, 22) that contain ribosome genes.
description.level5: Stalk regions containing ribosomal RNA genes (rDNA) found on acrocentric chromosomes.
description.level6: Secondary constrictions containing rDNA arrays encoding 18S, 5.8S, and 28S ribosomal RNA.
description.level7: Nucleolar organizer regions (NORs) containing ~400 copies of the 45kb rDNA repeat unit.
description.level8: NOR stalks contain tandem rDNA repeats transcribed by RNA Pol I, forming nucleoli during interphase.

shortDescription.level3: Losing a piece here can cause learning problems and health issues.
shortDescription.level4: A region where deletions cause 1p36 deletion syndrome - one of the most common deletion syndromes.
shortDescription.level5: The 1p36 region - deletions here cause developmental delay, seizures, and distinctive facial features.
shortDescription.level6: The 1p36 microdeletion syndrome region, the most common terminal deletion syndrome in humans.
shortDescription.level7: 1p36 deletions occur in ~1/5,000 births, causing intellectual disability, epilepsy, and cardiomyopathy.
shortDescription.level8: 1p36 deletions involve variable breakpoints; haploinsufficiency of SKI, GABRD, and other genes contributes to phenotype.

funFact.level3: This is the most common chromosome tip deletion that doctors find!
funFact.level4: About 1 in 5,000 babies is born with a deletion in this region!
funFact.level5: 1p36 deletion syndrome is the most common subtelomeric deletion syndrome.
funFact.level6: First described in 1981, now recognized as the most common terminal deletion syndrome.
funFact.level7: Most 1p36 deletions are de novo (not inherited) and occur at varying breakpoints.
funFact.level8: 1p36 deletion phenotype variability correlates with deletion size and specific gene content.

shortDescription.level3: Where two ape chromosomes stuck together to make human chromosome 2!
shortDescription.level4: The spot where two ancestral chromosomes fused - proof of human evolution!
shortDescription.level5: The telomere-telomere fusion site showing where ancestral ape chromosomes merged.
shortDescription.level6: Contains remnant telomeric sequences marking the fusion of ancestral chromosomes 2A and 2B.
shortDescription.level7: Head-to-head telomeric repeats (TTAGGG)n mark the fusion point that created human chromosome 2.
shortDescription.level8: The 2q13-14 fusion junction contains degenerate telomeric arrays diagnostic of ancestral chromosome fusion.

funFact.level3: This is why humans have 46 chromosomes but chimps have 48!
funFact.level4: You can still see the old chromosome ends stuck in the middle!
funFact.level5: The telomeric DNA 'fossils' here prove human and ape chromosomes share common ancestry.
funFact.level6: The fusion occurred ~4-5 million years ago after human-chimp divergence.
funFact.level7: This fusion site is one of the most compelling cytogenetic proofs of human evolution.
funFact.level8: The 2q fusion site demonstrates that the human karyotype arose from a Robertsonian-like fusion event.

shortDescription.level3: An old chromosome center that doesn't work anymore!
shortDescription.level4: A leftover centromere from the chromosome fusion - turned off but still visible.
shortDescription.level5: The vestigial centromere from ancestral chromosome 2B, silenced after fusion.
shortDescription.level6: Contains degraded alpha satellite sequences from the inactivated ancestral centromere.
shortDescription.level7: Vestigial alphoid DNA lacking CENP-A deposition, representing the silenced 2B centromere.
shortDescription.level8: The 2q21 vestigial centromere shows epigenetic silencing of formerly functional centromeric chromatin.

funFact.level3: When chromosomes merge, one centromere has to be turned off or the cell gets confused!
funFact.level4: This 'ghost centromere' is evidence of the ancient chromosome fusion.
funFact.level5: Having two active centromeres would tear the chromosome apart during cell division!
funFact.level6: Dicentric chromosomes are unstable; one centromere must be inactivated.
funFact.level7: Centromere inactivation was essential for the fusion chromosome to be stably inherited.
funFact.level8: Rapid epigenetic centromere silencing enabled the fusion chromosome to achieve mitotic stability.

shortDescription.level3: Where the Huntington's disease gene lives.
shortDescription.level4: Contains the HTT gene - too many CAG repeats here cause Huntington's disease.
shortDescription.level5: The HTT gene location - CAG repeat expansion causes Huntington's disease.
shortDescription.level6: Contains HTT where CAG trinucleotide expansion (>36 repeats) causes Huntington's disease.
shortDescription.level7: The HTT gene has CAG repeats encoding polyglutamine; expansion causes toxic aggregation.
shortDescription.level8: HTT CAG expansion causes polyQ aggregation, transcriptional dysregulation, and selective striatal neurodegeneration.

funFact.level3: The more repeats in this gene, the younger you get sick - it's very predictable!
funFact.level4: Woody Guthrie, the famous folk singer, had Huntington's disease.
funFact.level5: HD was one of the first genes mapped by linkage analysis before the genome was sequenced!
funFact.level6: The HD gene was mapped in 1983 and cloned in 1993 after a 10-year search.
funFact.level7: Huntington's shows anticipation - repeat length increases through paternal transmission.
funFact.level8: HTT was mapped to 4p16.3 using restriction fragment length polymorphisms in Venezuelan families.

shortDescription.level3: Problems here can make kids grow really fast and really tall!
shortDescription.level4: Contains the NSD1 gene - mutations cause Sotos syndrome (overgrowth).
shortDescription.level5: The NSD1 gene location - haploinsufficiency causes Sotos syndrome with overgrowth.
shortDescription.level6: NSD1 encodes a histone methyltransferase; loss causes Sotos syndrome with macrocephaly and overgrowth.
shortDescription.level7: NSD1 haploinsufficiency via deletion or point mutation causes ~90% of Sotos syndrome cases.
shortDescription.level8: NSD1 (H3K36 methyltransferase) loss disrupts epigenetic regulation causing accelerated growth and intellectual disability.

funFact.level3: Kids with this condition can be much taller than other kids their age!
funFact.level4: Sotos syndrome causes 'overgrowth' - affected children are unusually tall with large heads.
funFact.level5: NSD1 controls how fast you grow - losing one copy makes you grow too fast!
funFact.level6: Japanese cases often have deletions; Western cases more often have point mutations.
funFact.level7: The high deletion rate in Japan relates to flanking segmental duplications.
funFact.level8: NAHR between flanking low-copy repeats causes the common ~2.2 Mb Sotos deletion in Japanese patients.

shortDescription.level3: Your immune system ID card genes live here!
shortDescription.level4: The HLA region - contains the genes that make you unique to your immune system.
shortDescription.level5: The major histocompatibility complex (MHC/HLA) - the most polymorphic region in the human genome.
shortDescription.level6: The HLA region spans ~4 Mb and contains genes for immune recognition and antigen presentation.
shortDescription.level7: The MHC contains >200 genes including highly polymorphic HLA class I and II molecules.
shortDescription.level8: The MHC region has the highest gene density in the genome with extensive LD and disease associations.

funFact.level3: These genes are why organ transplants need to be 'matched'!
funFact.level4: The HLA genes are so diverse that almost everyone has a unique combination!
funFact.level5: HLA genes determine transplant compatibility and autoimmune disease risk.
funFact.level6: Some HLA alleles have been maintained by balancing selection for millions of years.
funFact.level7: Trans-species polymorphism at HLA predates human-chimp divergence by millions of years.
funFact.level8: HLA polymorphism is maintained by pathogen-driven balancing selection with >10,000 known alleles.

shortDescription.level3: Where the cystic fibrosis gene lives.
shortDescription.level4: Contains CFTR - mutations here cause cystic fibrosis.
shortDescription.level5: The CFTR gene - mutations cause cystic fibrosis, the most common lethal genetic disease in Caucasians.
shortDescription.level6: CFTR encodes a chloride channel; loss-of-function mutations cause cystic fibrosis.
shortDescription.level7: ΔF508 (deletion of phenylalanine 508) accounts for ~70% of CF alleles worldwide.
shortDescription.level8: CFTR modulators (ivacaftor, lumacaftor) have transformed CF from fatal to treatable disease.

funFact.level3: About 1 in 25 white people carry a CF gene mutation but don't know it!
funFact.level4: New medicines can now help many people with CF live much longer!
funFact.level5: Carrying one CF mutation might have protected ancestors from cholera!
funFact.level6: The heterozygote advantage theory suggests CF carriers resisted cholera or typhoid.
funFact.level7: CFTR was cloned in 1989 using positional cloning - a landmark achievement.
funFact.level8: CFTR cloning pioneered the positional cloning approach before the genome was sequenced.

shortDescription.level3: A gene here helps people learn to talk!
shortDescription.level4: Contains FOXP2 - the 'language gene' important for speech and language.
shortDescription.level5: FOXP2, the first gene linked to speech and language development.
shortDescription.level6: FOXP2 encodes a transcription factor essential for language; mutations cause verbal dyspraxia.
shortDescription.level7: FOXP2 mutations in the KE family revealed its role in speech motor control and language.
shortDescription.level8: FOXP2 has two human-specific substitutions; Neanderthals shared these variants.

funFact.level3: This gene is sometimes called the 'talking gene'!
funFact.level4: A family with mutations in this gene had trouble speaking and making mouth movements.
funFact.level5: Neanderthals had the same FOXP2 version as modern humans!
funFact.level6: FOXP2 mutations were discovered in the KE family, half of whom had severe speech problems.
funFact.level7: FOXP2 underwent a selective sweep ~200,000 years ago in the human lineage.
funFact.level8: FOXP2 regulates >300 genes in the brain including CNTNAP2 and SRPX2.

shortDescription.level3: This spot affects your chances of heart disease!
shortDescription.level4: A 'gene desert' that strongly affects heart disease risk - we're still figuring out how.
shortDescription.level5: The 9p21 locus - the first and strongest GWAS hit for coronary artery disease.
shortDescription.level6: Contains CDKN2A/B and ANRIL; variants affect cardiovascular and cancer risk through unclear mechanisms.
shortDescription.level7: 9p21 variants affect ANRIL lncRNA expression and cell proliferation, influencing atherosclerosis.
shortDescription.level8: The 9p21 risk locus demonstrates that 'gene deserts' can harbor crucial regulatory elements.

funFact.level3: There are almost no regular genes here, but it still affects heart disease!
funFact.level4: Scientists call this a 'gene desert' but it's not empty - there's hidden important stuff!
funFact.level5: The 9p21 region shows that non-coding DNA can be just as important as genes!
funFact.level6: ~25% of people carry the high-risk 9p21 variant.
funFact.level7: The 9p21 region was the first major GWAS discovery for coronary disease (2007).
funFact.level8: 9p21 GWAS discovery helped validate the common disease-common variant hypothesis.

shortDescription.level3: An 'imprinted' region - it matters which parent it came from!
shortDescription.level4: Contains genes that work differently depending on if they came from mom or dad.
shortDescription.level5: A major imprinted region - genes here are expressed based on parental origin.
shortDescription.level6: Contains imprinted genes (IGF2, H19, CDKN1C) with complex parent-of-origin effects.
shortDescription.level7: Dysregulation causes Beckwith-Wiedemann (overgrowth) or Silver-Russell (undergrowth) syndromes.
shortDescription.level8: The 11p15.5 imprinted cluster demonstrates reciprocal imprinting with growth effects.

funFact.level3: Some genes only work if they come from mom, others only from dad!
funFact.level4: Problems here can make babies grow too big or too small!
funFact.level5: This region shows why both mom and dad's contributions are necessary!
funFact.level6: Parthenogenetic embryos fail because they lack paternal IGF2 expression.
funFact.level7: 11p15 imprinting involves differentially methylated regions established in the germline.
funFact.level8: The 11p15 region contains two independently regulated imprinted domains (ICR1 and ICR2).

shortDescription.level3: Where the first cancer gene was found!
shortDescription.level4: Contains RB1 - the first tumor suppressor gene ever discovered.
shortDescription.level5: The RB1 gene - its discovery founded our understanding of tumor suppressors.
shortDescription.level6: RB1 loss causes retinoblastoma; its discovery established the two-hit hypothesis.
shortDescription.level7: Knudson's two-hit model based on RB1 explained hereditary vs sporadic cancer.
shortDescription.level8: RB1 cloning (1986) confirmed the two-hit hypothesis and defined tumor suppressor biology.

funFact.level3: Scientists figured out how cancer genes work by studying this region!
funFact.level4: The 'two-hit hypothesis' for cancer came from studying this gene!
funFact.level5: RB1 was the first tumor suppressor gene cloned, revolutionizing cancer biology!
funFact.level6: Alfred Knudson proposed his famous hypothesis in 1971; RB1 was cloned in 1986.
funFact.level7: The Rb protein controls the G1/S cell cycle checkpoint.
funFact.level8: RB1 encodes a pocket protein that sequesters E2F transcription factors until CDK phosphorylation.

shortDescription.level3: Same missing piece causes different diseases depending on which parent it came from!
shortDescription.level4: An imprinted region - the same deletion causes different syndromes based on parental origin.
shortDescription.level5: Loss of paternal genes causes Prader-Willi; loss of maternal UBE3A causes Angelman syndrome.
shortDescription.level6: The paradigm imprinted region demonstrating reciprocal parent-of-origin effects.
shortDescription.level7: PWS results from loss of paternally expressed genes; AS from loss of maternal UBE3A.
shortDescription.level8: Complex imprinting regulation involves PWS-IC, AS-IC, snoRNAs, and long non-coding RNAs.

funFact.level3: The same missing piece causes different problems depending on if it came from mom or dad!
funFact.level4: This taught scientists that it matters WHICH parent you get certain genes from!
funFact.level5: Prader-Willi causes constant hunger; Angelman causes happy demeanor with seizures.
funFact.level6: These complementary syndromes proved genomic imprinting exists in humans.
funFact.level7: ~70% of cases are due to deletion; others from UPD or imprinting defects.
funFact.level8: PWS/AS demonstrates how imprinting can be disease-relevant and that both parents contribute uniquely.

shortDescription.level3: This is where your eye color genes live!
shortDescription.level4: Contains OCA2 and HERC2 - the main genes controlling eye color.
shortDescription.level5: The OCA2/HERC2 region explains most human eye color variation.
shortDescription.level6: HERC2 enhancer variants regulate OCA2 expression, determining blue vs brown eyes.
shortDescription.level7: rs12913832 in HERC2 explains ~74% of eye color variation in Europeans.
shortDescription.level8: The HERC2 intronic enhancer controls OCA2 transcription via differential chromatin looping.

funFact.level3: One tiny change in DNA can make your eyes blue instead of brown!
funFact.level4: Blue eyes appeared only about 6,000-10,000 years ago near the Black Sea!
funFact.level5: All blue-eyed people share a common ancestor from ~6,000-10,000 years ago!
funFact.level6: The blue-eye variant arose once and spread through European populations.
funFact.level7: Blue eyes may have been sexually selected in Northern European populations.
funFact.level8: The OCA2/HERC2 blue-eye haplotype shows signatures of positive selection in Europeans.

shortDescription.level3: A gene here can cause kidney problems.
shortDescription.level4: Contains PKD1 - mutations cause polycystic kidney disease.
shortDescription.level5: PKD1 mutations cause autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.
shortDescription.level6: PKD1 encodes polycystin-1; mutations cause ADPKD, the most common genetic kidney disease.
shortDescription.level7: ~85% of ADPKD is due to PKD1 mutations; cyst formation follows a two-hit model.
shortDescription.level8: PKD1 has complex genomic structure with multiple pseudogenes complicating mutation detection.

funFact.level3: This is one of the most common genetic diseases!
funFact.level4: About 1 in 500-1,000 people have mutations in this gene!
funFact.level5: PKD affects about 12 million people worldwide!
funFact.level6: PKD1 and TSC2 are adjacent; contiguous gene deletion causes a severe combined phenotype.
funFact.level7: ADPKD is the 4th most common cause of kidney failure requiring dialysis.
funFact.level8: Tolvaptan (vasopressin receptor antagonist) can slow PKD progression.

shortDescription.level3: The 'guardian of the genome' lives here!
shortDescription.level4: Contains TP53 - the most important cancer-preventing gene.
shortDescription.level5: TP53, the most frequently mutated gene in cancer, is located here.
shortDescription.level6: TP53 encodes p53, the 'guardian of the genome' controlling cell cycle and apoptosis.
shortDescription.level7: p53 is mutated in >50% of all cancers; Li-Fraumeni syndrome results from germline mutations.
shortDescription.level8: p53 integrates stress signals via N-terminal phosphorylation to activate or repress target genes.

funFact.level3: This gene is called the 'guardian of the genome' because it protects against cancer!
funFact.level4: More than half of all cancers have problems with this gene!
funFact.level5: P53 was voted 'Molecule of the Year' in 1993!
funFact.level6: Elephants have 20 copies of TP53, which may explain their low cancer rate.
funFact.level7: p53 was initially thought to be an oncogene before being recognized as a tumor suppressor.
funFact.level8: The discovery that wild-type p53 is a tumor suppressor revolutionized cancer biology.

shortDescription.level3: An important gene for preventing breast cancer lives here.
shortDescription.level4: Contains BRCA1 - mutations greatly increase breast and ovarian cancer risk.
shortDescription.level5: BRCA1, a major hereditary breast/ovarian cancer gene, is located here.
shortDescription.level6: BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor essential for DNA repair; mutations confer 70% lifetime breast cancer risk.
shortDescription.level7: BRCA1 participates in homologous recombination; deficiency enables PARP inhibitor therapy.
shortDescription.level8: BRCA1 recruits to DSBs via ABRAXAS complex, promoting end resection and RAD51 loading.

funFact.level3: Angelina Jolie has a BRCA1 mutation and told everyone to raise awareness!
funFact.level4: Knowing about BRCA1 mutations lets people take action to prevent cancer!
funFact.level5: About 1 in 400 people carry a BRCA1 mutation.
funFact.level6: Founder mutations are common in Ashkenazi Jewish (1 in 40) and Icelandic populations.
funFact.level7: BRCA1 was cloned in 1994 after intense competition between research groups.
funFact.level8: BRCA1 patenting led to the landmark Supreme Court case Association for Molecular Pathology v. Myriad.

shortDescription.level3: Having three copies of this region causes Down syndrome.
shortDescription.level4: The Down syndrome critical region - extra copies cause the characteristic features.
shortDescription.level5: The DSCR contains genes whose triplication contributes to Down syndrome phenotypes.
shortDescription.level6: Gene triplication in this region causes intellectual disability and congenital heart defects.
shortDescription.level7: DSCR1 and DYRK1A are key dosage-sensitive genes contributing to the DS phenotype.
shortDescription.level8: The DSCR hypothesis suggests a subset of 21q genes drive most DS phenotypes.

funFact.level3: Down syndrome happens when there are 3 copies of chromosome 21 instead of 2!
funFact.level4: Down syndrome is the most common chromosomal condition in humans.
funFact.level5: About 1 in 700 babies is born with Down syndrome.
funFact.level6: APP (Amyloid Precursor Protein) triplication causes early Alzheimer's in DS individuals.
funFact.level7: John Langdon Down described the syndrome in 1866; Jérôme Lejeune identified trisomy 21 in 1959.
funFact.level8: Mouse models with segmental trisomy have helped identify critical genes for specific DS phenotypes.

shortDescription.level3: Losing a piece here affects the heart, face, and immune system.
shortDescription.level4: The DiGeorge/velocardiofacial syndrome region - one of the most common microdeletions.
shortDescription.level5: 22q11.2 deletion causes DiGeorge syndrome with heart defects, immune problems, and cleft palate.
shortDescription.level6: The 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (incidence ~1/4,000) is caused by NAHR between flanking LCRs.
shortDescription.level7: TBX1 haploinsufficiency causes most cardiac and pharyngeal features.
shortDescription.level8: The 3 Mb deletion contains ~40 genes; variable expressivity relates to modifier genes and stochastic effects.

funFact.level3: This deletion is also linked to higher risk of mental health problems.
funFact.level4: About 1 in 4,000 people is born with this deletion!
funFact.level5: 22q11.2 deletion is the second most common chromosomal abnormality after Down syndrome!
funFact.level6: ~25% of 22q11.2 deletion carriers develop schizophrenia.
funFact.level7: COMT haploinsufficiency may contribute to psychiatric manifestations.
funFact.level8: The 22q11.2 region is prone to NAHR due to flanking low-copy repeats (LCR22s).

shortDescription.level3: The biggest gene in the human body lives here!
shortDescription.level4: Contains DMD - the largest human gene, mutations cause muscular dystrophy.
shortDescription.level5: The DMD gene spans 2.2 Mb - when mutated, muscles progressively weaken.
shortDescription.level6: DMD (dystrophin) is the largest human gene at 2.2 Mb with 79 exons.
shortDescription.level7: Frame-shifting mutations cause Duchenne MD; in-frame deletions cause milder Becker MD.
shortDescription.level8: Dystrophin links F-actin to the dystroglycan complex; its absence causes sarcolemmal instability.

funFact.level3: This gene is so big it takes 16 hours just to read it!
funFact.level4: Because it's on the X chromosome, mostly boys are affected.
funFact.level5: DMD is so large that it takes 16 hours to transcribe from DNA to RNA!
funFact.level6: The gene's huge size makes it a large target for mutations - 1/3 are de novo.
funFact.level7: Exon-skipping therapies can restore the reading frame for specific mutations.
funFact.level8: Gene therapy using micro-dystrophin constructs is in clinical trials.

shortDescription.level3: Too many DNA repeats here can cause learning problems.
shortDescription.level4: Contains FMR1 - repeat expansion causes Fragile X syndrome.
shortDescription.level5: FMR1 CGG repeat expansion causes Fragile X, the most common inherited intellectual disability.
shortDescription.level6: CGG expansion >200 repeats causes methylation and silencing of FMR1, causing Fragile X.
shortDescription.level7: Full mutations cause loss of FMRP; premutations can cause FXTAS and ovarian insufficiency.
shortDescription.level8: FMRP regulates mRNA transport and local synaptic translation via mGluR5 signaling.

funFact.level3: The chromosome looks 'fragile' or broken at this spot under a microscope!
funFact.level4: The gene got its name because the X chromosome looks fragile at that spot!
funFact.level5: Premutation carriers (55-200 repeats) can develop different problems than full mutations!
funFact.level6: ~1 in 150 females and 1 in 450 males carry premutations.
funFact.level7: The repeat expands through maternal transmission but rarely through paternal.
funFact.level8: CGG repeat expansion involves replication slippage and MSH2-dependent instability.

shortDescription.level3: Your red and green color vision genes are here!
shortDescription.level4: Contains the red and green color vision genes - rearrangements cause color blindness.
shortDescription.level5: The OPN1LW and OPN1MW genes for red and green vision - unequal crossing over causes color blindness.
shortDescription.level6: Tandemly arrayed red/green opsin genes are prone to NAHR causing color vision defects.
shortDescription.level7: ~8% of males have red-green color vision deficiency due to gene deletion or hybrid formation.
shortDescription.level8: Opsin gene copy number and arrangement determines the specific color vision phenotype.

funFact.level3: About 1 in 12 boys is colorblind - and this is why!
funFact.level4: Girls are rarely colorblind because they have two X chromosomes as backup!
funFact.level5: Some women have FOUR types of color vision cones due to variations here!
funFact.level6: Heterozygous females may have tetrachromatic vision with enhanced color discrimination.
funFact.level7: Gene conversion between red and green opsins generates hybrid genes with altered spectral sensitivity.
funFact.level8: Opsin gene cluster evolution demonstrates how tandem duplications create variation and disease.

shortDescription.level3: The gene that makes boys into boys!
shortDescription.level4: Contains SRY - the master switch that triggers male development.
shortDescription.level5: SRY is the testis-determining factor - it initiates male development.
shortDescription.level6: SRY encodes a transcription factor that triggers the male developmental cascade.
shortDescription.level7: SRY activates SOX9 expression, which then maintains testis development.
shortDescription.level8: SRY evolved from SOX3 through gene translocation and functional divergence ~166 MYA.

funFact.level3: This tiny gene decides if someone becomes a boy or a girl!
funFact.level4: Without this gene, everyone would develop as female by default!
funFact.level5: SRY is only ~900 bp long but has a huge effect!
funFact.level6: XX individuals with translocated SRY develop as males.
funFact.level7: SRY acts as a genetic switch during week 7 of development.
funFact.level8: The default mammalian developmental pathway is female; SRY actively overrides this.
